title: BiogENesis and Degradation of Endoplasmic Reticulum proteins
descriptions:
Abstract:

The "BiogENesis and Degradation of Endoplasmic Reticulum proteins" project aims to unravel the complex network of protein biogenesis, folding, and degradation within the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) of eukaryotic cells. Leveraging cutting-edge Cryo-electron tomography (CET) coupled with sophisticated computational analysis, this research seeks to provide unprecedented subnanometer resolution images of the ER protein network. Our objectives are to explore the molecular details of ER protein biogenesis and homeostasis, including the structure and dynamics of the ER translocon, the multifaceted process of cotranslational ER import, N-glycosylation, chaperone-mediated stabilization, folding, oligomerization of model substrates like the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) classes I and II, and the degradation of misfolded proteins via the cytosolic 26S proteasome.

Our methods include CET of cellular and cell-free systems, computational sub-tomogram averaging, and in silico purification, which will advance our understanding of native macromolecular states. We aim to provide a new blueprint for structural biology research on membrane-associated processes. The research will also study the ER-bound translation machinery's structural changes under ER stress conditions, particularly focusing on IRE1-mediated mRNA degradation.

The implications of this project are far-reaching, with potential contributions to understanding chronic diseases related to ER stress, such as diabetes and neurodegenerative disorders. Additionally, it will offer insights into viral immune evasion and glycosylation disorders, paving the way for novel therapeutic approaches. Our project promises a comprehensive look at the ER protein network, with the goal of elucidating mechanisms that maintain cellular health and contribute to disease pathogenesis.

Abstract:

The "BiogENesis and Degradation of Endoplasmic Reticulum proteins" project represents a transformative approach to elucidating the intricate processes governing the biogenesis and homeostasis of proteins within the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) network of eukaryotic cells. Utilizing the cutting-edge Cryo-electron tomography (CET) technology paired with advanced computational analysis and innovative 'in silico purification' methods, the project aims to provide unprecedented structural insights at subnanometer resolution.

Specific objectives of the project include revealing the molecular details of ER protein biogenesis and homeostasis and studying the structure and dynamics of the ER translocon. The project will investigate key processes such as cotranslational ER import, N-glycosylation, chaperone-mediated stabilization, folding, and oligomerization using model substrates like the Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I and II. It will also explore the degradation pathways of misfolded proteins residing in the ER by the cytosolic 26S proteasome and examine the structural changes in the ER-bound translation machinery during ER stress, particularly the IRE1-mediated mRNA degradation mechanism.

The project's methodologies encompass CET of both cellular and cell-free systems, computational analysis for sub-tomogram averaging, and subtomogram classification for 'in silico purification' to analyze various states of native macromolecules. This research will serve as a blueprint for a new paradigm in the structural biology of membrane-associated processes.

Anticipated applications and implications of this research range from enhancing our understanding of viral immune evasion mechanisms and glycosylation disorders to providing insights into diseases characterized by chronic ER stress, such as diabetes and neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed project promises to significantly advance the field of cellular biology and contribute to the development of potential therapeutic interventions for a variety of pathological conditions linked to ER dysfunction.

Abstract:

The "BiogENesis and Degradation of Endoplasmic Reticulum proteins" project aims to elucidate the intricate processes governing the biogenesis and homeostatic regulation of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) proteins. By employing cutting-edge Cryo-electron tomography (CET) complemented with advanced computational analysis and sub-tomogram averaging, this research will provide unprecedented structural insights at subnanometer resolution into the ER protein network of eukaryotic cells. The project encompasses a detailed investigation of the ER translocon, the gateway for cotranslational import and N-glycosylation, and the folding and oligomerization of model substrates, including Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) class I and II molecules. 

A central objective is to reveal the molecular details of ER protein biogenesis and homeostasis, focusing on the structure and dynamics of the translocon. Additionally, the study will address how the ER machinery responds to misfolded proteins, employing the 26S proteasome system as a model for degradation. This aspect is particularly relevant to understanding how the cytomegalovirus manipulates the immune system by depleting MHC class I molecules. The project will also scrutinize the structural changes in the ER-bound translation machinery under conditions of ER stress, closely examining the IRE1-mediated mRNA degradation pathway. 

Further, the research will refine and apply 'in silico purification' techniques to various native macromolecular states, enhancing the field's ability to study membrane-associated processes. The expected contributions of this project are manifold, promising new perspectives in structural biology, insights into viral immune evasion, glycosylation disorders, and the etiology of diseases associated with chronic ER stress, such as diabetes and neurodegenerative diseases. Overall, the proposed study will set a new blueprint for understanding and manipulating the ER protein network, with far-reaching implications for biomedical research and therapeutic development.

Abstract:

The "BiogENesis and Degradation of Endoplasmic Reticulum proteins" project proposes a groundbreaking study of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) protein network in eukaryotic cells. By leveraging the power of Cryo-electron tomography (CET) and advanced computational analysis, this research seeks to elucidate the complex processes of protein biogenesis and homeostasis within the ER with subnanometer resolution. The project's objectives are to reveal the molecular intricacies of the ER protein biogenesis and homeostasis, examine the structure and dynamics of the ER translocon, and provide unprecedented insights into the cotranslational import, N-glycosylation, stabilization, folding, and oligomerization of model substrates such as the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) classes I and II.

Additionally, the proposed research will investigate the degradation pathways of misfolded ER proteins via the cytosolic 26S proteasome using cytomegalovirus-induced depletion of MHC class I as a model system. It will also assess the structural response of the ER-bound translation machinery during ER stress, particularly focusing on IRE1-mediated mRNA degradation mechanisms. An innovative aspect of this project is the improvement of 'in silico purification' techniques, which is expected to enhance the study of various states of native macromolecules.

This project stands to make significant contributions by developing a new approach to the structural biology of membrane-associated processes. The implications of this research are far-reaching, with the potential to advance our understanding of viral immune evasion mechanisms, glycosylation disorders, and diseases associated with chronic ER stress, such as diabetes and neurodegenerative conditions. By providing a comprehensive blueprint of ER protein networks, this proposal aims to facilitate breakthroughs in molecular biology that can translate into therapeutic strategies for a range of diseases.
